Fittle is an accessible learning toolset for visually challenged kids, in the form of a playful puzzle. By feeling braille letters embossed on the word blocks, and then feeling the shape that s/he has fit together, the kid can touch what the object might feel like in real. We are currently testing the beta version.  
We present to you, our second Fittle (beta), the Train.  
Check out more details about Fittle at www.fittle.in

You can print the 3 parts separately, or at the same time, depending on the printing area your printer provides. Make sure that the width of the block is 25mm.  
Best printed in ABS. Try to scrape off the support material while fresh off the printer. Try not to touch the braille dots till it has cooled off completely.

This thing has a couple of replacement dishwasher parts:

  • The runner/slider that attaches the upper rack to the slider rails. The original had wheels at two heights but we only ever used the top wheel.

  • Replacement cutlery basket bottoms. The grid is a two-level deal to keep the cutlery ends distributed on the bottom of the basket rather than all ending up in the corners.

The slider piece has built-in support structures that you will need to snap/cut off after printing. I think it may be a fairly standard part, but you can adjust parameters in the openscad source if you want. Given that it bears 1/4 of the weight of the top rack, you should print with fairly high infill.
For the cutlery basket grids, either directly size the STLs to whatever size you need, or use the modules in the openscad source to make a custom grid.

title: Backlash Reducer for Delta printer 6 mm rod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a stronger backlash reducer for the Delta 3D printers using 6mm rods and ball joints.
This backlash reducer reduces the play in the ball joint by gently forcing them together.

It's a hinged mechanism that is finally screwed togeter to get a very solid connection and no risk of spring/rubber band to slip off.

Things needed:
6 pcs Backlash Reducers
6 pcs M3x8 screw (or M3x10 or M3x12)
6 pcs M3 lock nut
3 pcs spring or rubbed band of appropriate size.

These can be mounted in 2 ways:

  • Center on the rods.
  • At the end of the rods (needs 2X the number of parts, but will be more gentle on the rod ends)

[No-Hinge Version]
Added a new version called "Backlash_Adapter_2_2-14_No_Hinge.STL" that does not use a hinge, this will be useful if your printer has too much oozing or similar issues.

[DONATIONS]
If you're enjoying this design and find it improves your print quality, please consider sending a tip.
Click "TIP DESIGNER" here.

title: Updated wheels for Cubelets modular robot, with freewheel option

description.text:
This is an extension and improvement of my previous Cubelets wheels. Cubelets are a system for quickly building highly functional robots, made by Modular Robotics. The wheels are designed to attach to the Rotate Cubelet, and let you make wheeled vehicles, mars rovers, etc. This complements the existing Drive Cubelet, which uses a system of tiny rollers on one face of the Cube.

I've made some significant changes: first, the design of the wheels has been changed to make it look cooler and more futuristic, vs sort of steampunk; second, there is a variation of the wheel that is designed to spin freely. This can be attached to any Cubelet, and used as a non-driven wheel. This is useful because now you can build a 4 wheeled vehicle using only two Rotate cubelets. It also prevents issues when using multiple motors that are not exactly synced in speed.

The freewheel version has a plain hub, while the version that locks onto a motor has a subtle decoration on it. Helps to tell them apart.

The attached OpenSCAD file will let you vary things like the diameter of the wheels, the O-Rings, bearing size, etc. I have found that there is really not much leeway on the size of the washers, it is pretty closely matched to the diameter of the Cubelets connector.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The only key thing here is to print the wheels with support, so that it fills in the well where the connector snaps in. It's quite a long span, so if your printer does not do bridging super well, you should really use support.

The connector should not require support, though it can't hurt.

Here's how you assemble these:

You will need:

  • Steel washers, 1" OD, 1/2" ID, 1/8" thick
  • Roller bearings, 22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm thick (apologies for mixing SAE and Metric)
  • O-rings, 2 7/8" OD, 2 1/2" ID
  • Magnets (optional) 1/8" x 1/8" cylinder

Make sure your washers are ferrous metal! I ordered some fancy washers from McMaster Carr and they were nickel alloy, and did not work. The cheap ones from the hardware store worked great.

For the basic version, the one that will lock onto a Rotate Cubelet and act as a driving wheel, print the "future wheel deco" using support material. This will fill in the well in the middle. Also print the "sleeved connector" piece. Clean the support out from the wheel, place the washer in the connector, and then snap it into place. You can use glue too, it will help.

For the freewheel version, the one that spins freely, do this: Print the "future wheel freewheel" using support. Print the freewheel pin, the freewheel hub, and sleeved connector freewheel (this has a socket for the pin). Clean the support from the wheel. Place the washer in the connector, and then snap it into the freewheel hub. Snap the freewheel pin into the socket on the back of the connector. You will see that it is keyed, so that it will only go in the proper way. Make sure it is seated all the way into the socket!

Then, get the wheel and put the bearing into the deep part of the well. Press it all the way in. It should be all the way in the well, and recessed about 1mm past the edge. There are some little nubs around the edge of the well to help hold it in place.

Now take the assembled connector and carefully press the pin into the bearing. Press it all the way in, it should snap crisply into place.

Slide the O-Rings over the wheel, and you are in business. You will need to use Cubelets Flash to reprogram the Rotate cubes on opposite sides to spin counter-clockwise, if you want to make a conventional drive.

NOTE ABOUT MAGNETS: Using small magnets around children can present a risk if swallowed. However, using the magnets does improve the connection. If your kids are old enough to know better, or well supervised, use the magnets. This version of the connector includes holes for 1/8" by 1/8" cylindrical magnets. There will be 1 layer of filament across the bottom of the hole to allow for bridging. Clean it out using a knife. If you do use the magnets, use a strong adhesive like epoxy or JB Weld, fill the holes with glue, and then press in the magnets. Bear in mind that the magnets have a polarity. You want to install them so that they REPEL the magnets on the Cubelet connector, that way when you attach them to a robot the magnets will repel each other and instead seek out the strike plates.

author: SF1968

description.text:
What!? No guns? Where's the old ultra violence, you say? I know nothing of knitting. My sister in law asked for a loom that could come apart. I said ok.
She hasn't told me she hates it yet. I believe she wanted it for knitting an "infinity scarf(?)". I have not tried knitting with this.

Print at least 1 "Break_Loom_v3_Barb", and 3 "Break_Loom_v3". The "Break_Loom_v3r" model can be used to created larger loom shapes. Print it sturdy. The spires have integral supports built into them. They require an unnecessary force for knitting to break. Extra walls, and at least .2 infill should suffice. Your gcode may treat the female connecter oddly. It is ok if the circular part prints funky. The inner ring is more of a guide for the sturdy outside supports.

comments.text: Great design, but it was absolute hell to make in PLA. I shattered three pieces before I finally got it to work (kinda - the one piece actually has a crack in it. But it doesn't appear to affect structural stability or functionality, so I'm going with it).

This is my second bathroom robot (the first one is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1409367 )

What can I say, it's a robot-shaped toilet paper holder.

The model has 3 parts - the robot itself, the wall plate and the rod. all of them should be printed with no support the body has built in support and the other files don't need any.

The body should be printed lying on it's back, there's 3 lines of support material that should be removed in the wall plate slot on the bottom and a lot of extra clearance so there are no problem with sagging due to bridging.

There are also supports below the arms and inside the hands, no additional supports are needed.

The wall plate should be printed wide part down, it does not require any support

And finally the rod, it's best to print it standing with the wider ring on the bottom - if your printer z-axis is long enough.

You should test-print a small part of the rod and see if it fits inside the hand, it's a little tight and you might have to scale it if you printer is calibrated differently then mine.

Everything can be printed on the same bed with the same settings if you have the build area but I think it looks better if the rod is a different color.

I printed everything in PLA, 0.2mm layer hight with 5% infill and 1.2mm shell (except for the rod that I accidentally printed with 0.4mm shell, I'll reprint it if it breaks).

I designed the model with SketchUp Make, fixed it with Microsoft 3D Builder, sliced it with Cura and printed my Robo3D R1+

title: Skoda Yeti door pocket trashbin (or anythingelsebin)

description.text:
There are things, like, say apple cores, that you can't always immediately dispose, but you don't want them lying around and exercise their free will. So I made this thing to limit their migration within the door pocket and isolate from whatever else may happen to be in the same compartment.

To save myself some trouble of taking measurements I used dimensions of the thing this is a remix of and also borrowed clip from there.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed it opening to the platform with no supports. Printer needs to be capable of bridging well for best results. I didn't master easily detachable supports, so I opted out of using any supports, but you know your printer better.

This was some 4 hours print for me at ~60mm/s using KISSLicer.

title: Fabrikator Mini Base w/40mm Fan Mount

description.text:
This is an updated version of Chuck Hellebuyck's FabMini base(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1057404) I added support structure for a thin 40mm fan to keep air circulating underneath the printer. Helps keep the stepper drivers cooler.

The orientation of the fan support is such that you can still use the LCD mount that Chuck designed.
Fan is mounted on top of the support so that it can draw air from underneath and blow it up at the control board. Wire the fan into the power block on the control board.

author: 3Dog_Modeling

description.text:
Here is a bracket that is designed to house a .28" voltmeter and a snap in 2 pole rocker switch.

Voltmeter used: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IWLU8YC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00

Rocker Switch used: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B008TOXRSQ?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00

It attaches to the top base plate on the Rostock max with two m3x20mm screws after you drill clearance holes in the top plate for them.

This setup will allow you to see your machine's voltage and use an auxiliary power source on a switch for LED's or whatever you want to wire to it.

Edit 8/2/2016: I created a housing that mounts off the bottom base because I enclosed my printer and the top mount was interfering. I included a 2-switch box to control 2 functions. I use one for my lights and one for the fan on my extruder stepper. I also changed my lighting since I had the enclosure. I decided to use this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239812

title: CTC LCD & Keypad Mount inc Tool Tray Bins & Tool bit holder

description.text:
So, there's already plenty of these mounts for the various printers and there clones, but this is one I put together for my CTC.

I originally came across http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71276 which I really likes, but the screen and keypad area were different on my CTC despite it being a replicator 1 clone.

That led me to start to make my own with the main "inspiration" from the thing linked above.

There are a few variants included depending on your tastes. As you can see from my pics I went for the one with the allen key holder + hex bit holder on the left side (with small "tray" under neath for nuts and screw when I'm pulling apart an extruder or something) and also with toolbins underneath. I don't personally use the SD card slot, so had no use or desire for the SD Card holder on mine, but I have included a variant of it.

If you're looking for a drilling guide, please use the drill guide found in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71276. It is close enough and will get you started - you can figure out the rest :)

You WILL need support obviously. Also, I used 25% infill and a 0.2 layer height. The walls are a little weak so I would recommend a higher % infill.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

You WILL need support obviously. Also, I used 25% infill and a 0.2 layer height. The walls are a little weak so I would recommend a higher % infill.

It is also large, so as per attached screenshot you will need to angle / position the item accordingly.

I used 10 brim lines to help ensure the piece stayed attached. (Printing on hairspray & glass)

This was my first print of the item, I may reprint it at a better quality (and lower bed temp since there was some base warping on mine) but it looks alright and does the job so may not.

Please refer to the "Remixed From" links on the right for credit to the inspiration. I didn't "design" this really, I just copied others and for want of better words, combined a mixture of other things.

remixed_from.author: GarageBay9
remixed_from.title: Open WarHex - modular, scenic 3D Hex terrain project

description.text:
WHAT THE TESTBED BRANCH IS:

This is a place where I upload experimental variants of the Open WarHex system that I'm either testing, considering, or putting up for feedback. THESE FILES MAY CHANGE AT ANY TIME AND THE OLD VERSIONS ARE PROBABLY GONE FOR GOOD WHEN THEY DO. This is more of a workbench than a specific thing.

Currently:
This is the core Open WarHex parts set, tweaked with a new contour for the central hex area and the modular ring; we're trying this as an experiment to see if people like the visual design of the less aggressive angles around the central hex.

It also has adjusted gutter widths to (hopefully) help stack more securely.

In addition, these changes are designed to give us more room to sculpt on the geometry for expansion parts such as roads, rubble, and other detailed terrain.

Please give it a try and upload feedback; if these changes are a keeper (or even mostly work), we'll either do further testing, roll them into the main OWH branch, or possibly all of the above!

UPDATE, 4-8-2016
After some test prints with the new central hex contours and module rings, I'm just not satisfied with the fit of the rings and the shallower height of the hexes; they don't stack as securely and the rings slide off very easily. I'm going to declare this a failed experiment, at least for my purposes, but I'll leave the Testbed branch up here until something else needs to go in this spot.

Printer:

Rostock Max

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Optional, I use around 5-10%

Notes:

Can be printed face-up or face down. If your printer struggles with the internal bridging under the central area, try printing face down. You will need to generate detachable supports beneath the edge gutter area around the central hex.

File is in decimal inches. If slicing in mm, multiply by 25.4

PLEASE GIVE FEEDBACK!

Let us know your thoughts on this design - what you like about it, what you don't like about it, why you even looked at it in the first place, how your prints went, how it worked in use, problems, or suggestions.

Also, please share pictures of your prints so we can make design tweaks if needed! The more user feedback we have, the better we can refine the design or adapt it for more variants (such as larger or smaller sizes).

remixed_from.author: claydegruchy
remixed_from.title: Customizable Maneuver Dial for X-Wing with naming

title: Customizable Maneuver Dial for X-Wing V2.2

description.text:
This is an updated version of Robert B. Ross' Customizable Maneuver Dial for X-Wing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:473972

It now enables you to add the new maneuvers (Segnor's Loop and Tallon Roll) to your maneuver dial, and other symbols have been adjusted to resemble the original symbols better and to be recognizable quickly despite now having many similar symbols. (For example rounded edges for banks and the Koiogran Turn.)

The customizer now also automatically adjusts the spacing between the symbols according to the number of maneuvers you entered. (12-20 maneuvers are supported automatically. TIE/fo's for example have 17 maneuvers.)

STL files for T-70 X-Wing and the first order TIE fighter maneuver dials included.

Update:
V2.1 features a custom symbol to display a "backwards" or "reverse" maneuver option for new experimental flight patterns. Usage as normal with a number and the character "B". (Currently not part of the original game)

V2.2 makes the "pinFit" variable more prominent, which is used to make sure the pin fits the hole perfectly, which has to be adjusted from printer to printer and has the option to print all three parts at once by setting the "part" variable to "all". Also can now print names on the dials, as implemented by claydegruchy here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1513653 with impact font for maximum clarity. STL files of the two new ships with names included.
Special thanks to the creators of 'text_on', their text script is amazing. You should check it out! Visit: https://github.com/brodykenrick/text_on_OpenSCAD
Also minor updates/corrections.

title: Conversion of continuous rotary motion to reciprocating rotary motion via a Pendulum gear

description.text:
This mechanism converts continuous rotary motion to reciprocating rotary motion.
First seen as a simulation example in SimLab Composer Mechanical.
Designed in Moment of Inspiration (Moi), simulated in SimLab Composer Mechanical and printed in Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker original.

A video of the finished print in action is here: https://youtu.be/b5-83VKwb5w
For a view without my hand in the way a simulation is here: https://youtu.be/zkBwzYbl3Sw
And an interactive 3D pdf file is included with the stl files.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Made in (Diamond Age) PLA.
For Engineering applications I normally use wall sections of 1.2mm (using a 0.4mm nozzle).
By default I use a brim which helps to keep the larger articles flat.
NOTE. I have NOT oriented the parts for printing. Some may be correctly oriented by chance but most are not and need careful checking for orientation and positioning before printing.

I clean the edges of screw holes with a tapered reamer, and bring to size the holes in which a shaft rotates with a hand (parallel) reamer.
NOTE that the hole in the handle to accept the handle stem should NOT be reamed to size as the stem is a light tap fit into the handle.
One thing to look out for in assembly is that the connector should be screwed to the gear 12 before the gear 77 is fixed to the connector.
I've used 3mm x 10mm long button head cap screws throughout.
I used, if I've counted correctly, 21 and there is provision for a further 2.

comments.text:
The gear whose motion I described as 'reciprocating rotary' is the small one with the pointer mounted on it.
I'm sorry that I didn't make that clear.
And I agree that 'reciprocating rotary' is a contradictory way of describing the motion.
Perhaps 'oscillating rotary' motion would have been a better term.
comments.author: mgg942

comments.text: This motion is not reciprocal, it doesn't fit a sin wave. If you watch the spokes of the "reciprocating" gear you can see that its overall motion is forward.

These hold a pair of 3/8" ID hydraulic hoses together. The OD on these hoses is ~3/4".

Two styles are provided.

The one clamp holds the hoses just with friction. You only need to print one of these. This is the one with the "bunny ears"

The second clamp requires a 1.5" long 1/4" bolt. Two pieces are printed for this version. This is the one with the hole through the middle.

The Q3D 220 is an FPV Racing frame designed for the 5" prop class with 3D printing in mind.

Features include:

  • X arm design with top mounting lipo capability provides excellent center of gravity.
  • SMA and battery lead mounting holes.
  • Access to vtx for easy swapping of channels.
  • Zip-tie holes for easy mounting of esc's.

It can be built in a couple different configurations with a 22mm internal cavity or a 30mm internal cavity.

Hardware required to complete frame 22mm version:
16 x M3 x 30mm bolts
16 x M3 Lock Nuts

Hardware required to complete frame 30mm version:
16 x M3 x 40mm bolts
16 x M3 Lock Nuts

It can be printed with almost any material but ABS is highly recommend.

4 shells and a minimum of 33% infill recommended for all parts.

Flight video of first prototype and maiden flight:
https://youtu.be/qmMbncKQCTI

Share pictures of your build on social media with the hashtag #Q3D220

I am releasing these files specifically for people interested in this hobby who want to build their first FPV racing drone. I know carbon fiber is a far superior material for racing but this is a fun build that can be put together very cheaply and will fly just as well. #GrowTheHobby

comments.text: Any way to use 1806 motors on this?
comments.author: Salter

comments.text: Awesome design. Looks strong. One question, were you seeing all that static in your fpv goggles? I ask because I know sometimes the dvr in the goggles exaggerates the noise. If you did have that much interference, bravo! That looks hard to fly like that. Thanks for sharing, this is on my "to do" list.
comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: Thanks, that was what I was seeing the facility we were flying in had an all metal roof making the reception terrible. You should have seen the ground stations we were running just to get that "good" of a image.
comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: Description doesn't say it, but this is designed for 1806 sized motors. I'll see if I can physically modify it to fit 2204's, but do you think you could add the holes in the file?
comments.author: CarterFansler

comments.text: This was designed for 2204 - 2206 motors
comments.author: CarterFansler

comments.text: Ah, I see. Your motor is....kinda special. It should look a bit like this, right? http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/catalog/89922_1_High.jpg
comments.author: questpact

comments.text: Thanks for the quad! I have one printed and am putting the electronics in. I'm using a fatshark 700 v2 camera and the lens wont fit through the hole, so I am going to have to make it a little bigger. How do you fasten the camera in there? Is it just friction fit?

comments.text: Hi great quad really strong.Printed in pet-g 30% infill 130g complete frame. Thanks!

comments.text: Naze 32, 2204 cobra motors, Rotor Geeks 20amp esc's, Fatshark Cmos 600tvl cam

comments.text: Hi there, do you happen to have the PID settings for this? :) Thanks!

Is it possibile to have the project files?

comments.author: eidos85

comments.text: what is the weight of just the 3d printed parts, excluding the hardware?
comments.author: AdmiralRoflknife

comments.text: It depends on the % infill you choose to print the arms... Between 22-33% will work great. The prototype in the images I built was 438g no battery and that was with 22% infill on everything printed. Although the hardware I used in the prototype was M4 not M3 so that will shave a lot of weight.

description.text: Great rival to the Altair 8800, the IMSAI 8080 generated more heat, but was made famous by a pre-teen Matthew Broderick in the movie WARGAMES.

1. Print out body.stl in light blue

  3. Print out 9 of button.stl, in a mix of red and blue

  6. Place the sticker on faceplate
  7. Glue the faceplate to the body.
  8. Hack into a nuclear missile base (please don't do this).

author: pcentobie

description.text:
I have been using Painless360's carriage clip for a while, which has been a bit of a love/hate relationship. I love when it works as intended, but I hate forgetting to remove it for the start of the next print. I'm eliminating the hate by converting the clip into a servo controlled device.

This is designed for a generic 9g servo motor. I'm running an MKS Gen controller board in my printer, which includes g-code addressable servo ports, so operating the servo will be pretty straight forward for me. For those of you still running the stock GT2560, sorry, no servo ports there. However, I have included a simple Arduino sketch to operate the servo, based upon a signal from one of the end-stop switches. I tested the Arduino solution using a Pro Mini, the code should be compatible across virtually the entire Arduino family. (You can see my Arduino breadboard operating in one of the photos, the blue wire comes from the end-stop switch.)

The lower latch part is easily removable, in case you need to disable the latch, e.g. during calibration, etc.

Update: I have discovered potential servo ports on the GT2560! The X_MIN and Y_MIN inputs are unused on this printer. Through the magic of Arduino, these ports can be reassigned to function as outputs to control servos.

As can be seen in the last photo, the board actually has 3 connections under the 2-pin endstop sockets, the extra one being +5v, exactly what is needed to power a servo. Be careful, the layout of these pins does not match the standard servo pinout (+5v should be in the middle).

Convert the X_MIN socket to 3-pins and connect it to the servo. In Repetier Firmware, enable Servo Support (Features tab) and assign the "Servo 0" pin as "X min endstop". (In the Mechanics tab, set the "X min" pin to "Disabled/No Pin".) Use the following G-code to control the latch servo:

M340 P0 S1500 ; Unlatch carriage (P0 = Servo 0, S1500 = mid position)
M340 P0 S2300 ; Enable carriage latch

(Marlin firmware may offer similar servo features, you'll have to work that out for yourself. I don't use Marlin anymore.)

While you're in there, convert the Y_MIN socket as well. I have something in the works which will use a second servo... 8)

description.text:
This file contains one half of a clamp that can be used to mount a
camera on the edge of 1/8" thick sheet of material. The two halves
are identical, so two of them form the clamp. Pass a 1/4" x 20
bolt through the hole in the mount, fix the other side with a nut
(tighten until the clamp grips the material), and that bolt should
screw into the tripod-mounting hole on the bottom of your
camera. The camera will be held such that you can shoot pictures
parallel to the plane of the material. To slide the clamp along the edge of your material, loosen the nut,
reposition, and retighten. To change the height of the camera
above the plane of material, use shorter or longer bolts, or adjust
the length by placing a second nut on the bolt on the side of the
clamp where the head of the bolt is.
Make two and screw together.  Instant clamping camera mount!

comments.text: So far, there is no precedent against copying for personal use.  Nor have the file-sharing cases said anything about person-to-person copying between friends.  Those of us who embrace a robust view of fair use believe that there are valid reasons for copying almost any book.  Digitizing your textbooks so you can annotate them and make/share electronic notes comes to mind as a perfect use case.
comments.author: vasile

comments.text: Liberating out of print, creative commons licensed books.  Or scanning your hand written books of poetry.  What else would you use it for?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We're mounting cameras to the Book Liberator! The Book Liberator is an open-source hardware/software project that will bring low-cost scanning of physical books to the masses. Our goal is super simple plans, dead-easy operation and low-cost kits/parts. We're getting close to a final design on our first prototype, and this clamp is one of the last pieces we need to stabilize. Check us out at http://bookliberator.combookliberator.com and feel free to get involved-- we could use a 3D printing expert on the team.

Warning! I had two of these and they fell off of my wall. I think it had more to do with the strips I used, though. However, I see the flaw in my design. It works better upside-down, but that way it does not have the lip that keeps the spool on.

Made to hold my spools of filament on the wall via adhesive strips. I used two large strips on the back.

Shown with duct tape for demonstration because I do not currently have a spare spool of filament.

The weight that it holds will largely depend on the adhesive strip used.

Mounting to the Wall

Add two large (or however many and whatever size you feel like) to the back of the holder and press against the wall firmly.

I would recommend you leave the 'tabs' facing downwards so they will be easily accessible in the future, but also hidden when the holder is holding a spool.

title: OpenForge 2.0 Cut Stone Full Base Customizer

description.text:
I've been asked if I could provide bases for OpenForge 2.0 that are basically the same as OpenForge 1.0. This customizer allows you to create bases of any size up to 6x6, and later when I upload some "External" tiles (what I used to call "Edge"), I'll add support for that here.

I also plan on adding some tiles with the base on as an option, using these bases as the source.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

author: devonjones

title: OpenForge 2.0 Cut Stone Magnetic Base Customizer

description.text:
This customizer lets you create your own stone magnetic bases for openforge. Presently, I generally use this style with Cut-Stone tiles and use the plain bases for tudor tiles. Depending on the printer you are using, you may want to use this to increase or decrease the size of the holes so you get the proper fit.

Many people don't use the filament rivet option, so you may want to turn that off (set it to 0). If you want to use the base with an inch based system (such as DragonLock), you can generate imperial scaled bases now as well.

If you are using construction kit pieces, I suggest adding the construction kit supports, as they give a greater gluing area.For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Instructions

There are five factors to consider when selecting a base.

1) The tile size. This will match between the tile and the base, such as 2x2 or 4x2.

2) The tile shape

  • square
  • diagonal
  • curved

3) The base style

  • plain
  • stone
  • ruined

2) What size basis do you want the tiles to be in. There are three choices:

  • 25mm - every square is 25mm on a side. This is compatible with Dwarven Forge. There is no need to scale the tile top with 25mm.
  • inch - every square is 1 inch (25.4 mm). This is compatible with Printable Scenery (OpenLOCK), DragonLOCK and HirstArts. Scale the tile top when you print it by 101.6% in the X and Y axes.
  • wyloch - every square is an inch and a quarter (31.75mm). This is compatible with hero's horde and wyloch tiles. Scale the tile top when you print it by 127% in the X and Y axes.

3) What connection system do you want to use. We offer 4 connectivity options:

  • Magnetic - uses 5mm spherical magnets. 1 each along the center of every square that is on the edge of the tile
  • Magnetic + OpenLOCK - uses 5mm spherical magnets. 1 each along the center of every square that is on the edge of the tile. Also has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square.
  • OpenLOCK - Has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square.
  • OpenLOCK Triplex - Has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square, and at the center of each square.
Changelog
  • 02/02/18 - Diagonals were misnamed, all ended in x4
  • 02/02/18 - inch and wyloch
  • 10/24/17 - Moved to a new version of the scad file, and uploaded new versions of all bases. Also added 25mm/inch/wyloch versions, and curved and diagonal versions.
  • 3/21/16 - Some bases updated. 2x3, 2x4, 3x2, 3x3, 3x4, 4x2, 4x3, 4x4. Rivet holes were not extending through to the other side on larger bases.
  • 8/30/16 - Updated customizer. Added ability to generate squares in the corners which is helpful for construction kit pieces, and added ability to scale the base up to inch based (for use with systems like DragonLock).
  • 10/26/16 - Switched the scaling into a system that can handle a different square basis for different systems. This allows it to work for Wyloch as well as being easily portable to any new size in the future
  • 11/11/16 - Added ability to make the base be solid.
  • 11/20/16 - Added ability to add braces

comments.author: tarrant

comments.text: I use 5mm spherical magnets.  The main problem with other magnets is that we can run into polarization problems, so I use captive sphere magnets so that they can spin appropriately to make the connection.  Trying to get everything working with where you place the positive and negative is almost certainly going to result in some tiles that don't work with each other.
